skill.author: Cain96

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill providing Git workflow guidance. No executable scripts, network calls, or malicious capabilities detected. The skill consists purely of markdown documentation explaining Git best practices.

content.value_statement: Writing good commits and managing branches is hard. This skill provides clear guidance on Git worktree workflows, conventional commits, and pull request best practices so your history stays clean and readable.
actual_capabilities: Guide Git worktree creation and management for parallel development
Explain Conventional Commit format with type and scope
Show commit trailer syntax for metadata like issues and co-authors
Provide PR description template and review checklist
Share advanced Git tips including rebase, cherry-pick, and bisect
limitations: Does not execute Git commands automatically
Does not integrate with Git hosting platforms like GitHub
Does not generate commit messages automatically
Does not create or manage branches directly

use_cases.title: Parallel feature development
use_cases.description: Use Git worktrees to work on multiple features without context switching or stashing.

use_cases.title: Enforce commit standards
use_cases.description: Apply Conventional Commits and PR templates across your team for consistent history.

use_cases.title: Submit quality contributions
use_cases.description: Follow best practices for commits and PRs that maintainers will appreciate.

prompt_templates.title: Create worktree
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Git worktree for a new feature called user-authentication in the parent directory.

prompt_templates.title: Write commit
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a Conventional Commit message for adding JWT token refresh to the auth module.

prompt_templates.title: Add trailer
prompt_templates.prompt: Add a commit trailer referencing GitHub issue #123 as the related issue.

prompt_templates.title: Review checklist
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me the PR review checklist before requesting review.

output_examples.input: How do I create a worktree for a bug fix?
output: This creates a new worktree at ../project-bugfix-login-error on branch fix/login-error
Types: feature, bugfix, hotfix, experiment, refactor

best_practices: Use Git worktrees for parallel work instead of stashing or switching branches
Follow Conventional Commits format with type, scope, and imperative mood
Keep PRs small and focused on one feature for easier review
anti_patterns: Committing directly to main without code review
Using vague commit messages like "fix bug" or "update"
Mixing unrelated changes into a single commit or PR

faq.question: What tools does this skill support?
faq.answer: It works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. The skill activates during Git operations and commits.

faq.question: What are the commit types?
faq.answer: The main types are feat, fix, docs, style, refactor, perf, test, build, ci, chore, and revert.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with CI/CD?
faq.answer: This skill provides guidance only. Integrate commit standards into CI using commit linters like commitlint.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. This is a read-only documentation skill. It does not access or store any repository data.

faq.question: Why use worktrees over branches?
faq.answer: Worktrees give you separate working directories. You can work on multiple branches simultaneously without switching.

faq.question: How is this different from Git aliases?
faq.answer: This skill explains Git concepts and best practices. Git aliases are shortcuts for commands you write yourself.
